Topic.Title: "Pretty much flawless" Watch Gartner analyst show off VMware View running on an NVIDIA GRID K2

Message.Msg: Paul Jacobs recently hired a high priest in computer industry (a veteran of IBM, AAPL, and some other tech giants) to be QC's board member, with the responsibility of guiding them toward this direction at an accelerated pace. Jacobs made a lot of noise to the tech press, as if something big was gonna happen tomorrow. Well, I was merely referring to their vague, but broad ambitions in this regard......they can collect all the cast-offs from dinosaurs companies and fantasize - remember that Intel guy who is now QC's worldwide marketing chief?)

Message.Title: Who Is Pre-Orderring A Shield?
Message.Msg: I'm getting one :)

Topic.Title: Digitimes: Microsoft to launch 8 inch Surface tablet in June, with NVIDIA procesors

Message.Msg: Combined reply to both ibexx and ashraf . . I think all the tablets using versions of Windows 8 hinge on whether Outlook can be used on that device. IMO, the Surface RT lack of use of Outlook really made the first tablets less attractive along with the price. I don't the chipset matters as much as the MS staples one can use on a particular tablet. I know that the lack of Outlook on Surface was keeping me from taking a serious look at Surface RT. So I'm believing MS is finally realizing they have to give more on RT which would make Tegra 4 a greater possibility for all the tablets concoctions by MS and help keep the costs down (when compared to Intel's first offerings).

I wont be preordering it but will likely get one at some point. My current card wont work with shield and that is vital for me to get it. So as much as I want to be an early adopter, my budget says Shield + New Graphics Card may be an issue this year. Hopefully NVDA brings in a good enough chunk of extra income and my budget can pretend nothing happened.
Wonderful another gamer who's going to BUY Shield and upgrade his GPC. I can see Nvidia throwing a Sale to get all those Low End Haswell grade Cards to Upgrade. Another way Shield is boosting sales!

I would be getting one if not for my Video Game Addict HSchooler - he's already got his PS3 controller to work with Android games on the N7 for months now - hauling the pair everywhere he goes - Shield would be perfect for him but I refuse to endorse his addiction.

Topic.Title: Digitimes: Microsoft to launch 8 inch Surface tablet in June, with NVIDIA procesors

Message.Msg: Can't agree with you more on Outlook. What are they thinking ? RT apps are scarce to begin with and they can't even get one of their own major app on this new platform ? Are they serious? They need to offer the full suit of their major software on RT as well not just the basics. However the pricing is the most important for mass acceptance.I hope they will price it no more than $50 above a similarly equipped tablet.

Message.Title: Titan is selling out
Message.Msg: Go to Newegg. They can't keep these things from flying off the shelf. GTX 780 (based on cut-down Titan) should also be a smash hit.
You need to fire your personal budget director. I would do it if this individual goes against my wish. :)

Message.Title: Interesting read: Shield rocks Google I/O
Message.Msg: blogsDOTnvidiaDOTcom/2013/05/shield-rocks-google-io/

As much as I'm a fan of Intel, I don't think Haswell will meaningfully eat into Nvidia's GPU business. No matter how good an IGP gets, games are a moving target, which means a dGPU will always be required. New game consoles will raise the minimum bar even higher.

Haswell will be as good as a one or two Keppler SMX card which is the lowest end Keppler cards available 6 months ago. And the next generation after Haswell will be as good as the entry level cards after the Keppler generation and so it goes.

Topic.Title: Interesting read: Shield rocks Google I/O

Message.Msg: thanx for pointing out. interesting.

Message.Title: Profit by checking out this guy right now.
Message.Msg: Has anybody taken a look at the articles being produced? Impressive material that will help any investor or trader. dFL8DOTme/3f843

I probably wouldnt go that far in comparison, but a big saving grace for Nvidia has and should be the driver support necessary for top level games. This is something Intel has proven it self incapable of for years, regardless of hardware capability.
Excellent point.

I think Intel's drivers get better, but Nvidia's really are the "gold standard". I find it very difficult to believe that they catch up in this regard. Spoke with reps from Nvidia the other day, they are very bullish on Kepler GPUs in Tegra. Can't wait for "Logan".

Message.Title: Shield pre-order moved up in response to growing buzz
Message.Msg: blogsDOTnvidiaDOTcom/2013/05/shield-pre-order/ You can order today, no need to wait till May 20th.

Message.Title: NVDA is unusually strong on a Friday
Message.Msg: Especially during the "lunch hour lull" which often coincides with the stock's LOD. As per WSJ, at this moment: Up volume exceeds down volume almost 2:1 Positive money flow: 5 million Just wondering if someone knows something about the Shield pre-order strength?
I don't think its in my best interest to fire Common Sense. He's usually spot on in his assessments... Now whether I listen enough, that is another story...

Topic.Title: NVDA is unusually strong on a Friday

Message.Msg: I dunno, I've been trawling through the tech sites to get a feel on the response it's getting, and it's only lukewarm, with a lot of people saying the price point is too high. I did read an interesting interview with a couple of Nvidia managers who said that the goal of Shield is mainly to get more attention for Tegra, and hopefully get developers associating Nvidia with mobile gaming more. I don't think they're expecting huge sales of this, but I think they've got more stuff coming down the pipe later so it doesn't matter if the thing is only modestly successful. techlandDOTtimeDOTcom/2013/05/16/nvidia-shield-not-priced-to-move-no-problem-for-nvidia/

Seriously, why should people by this? SHIED = 5" Android tablet + Oversized Controller. There are already tools out there for you to connect the xbox controller to work with Android which cost less than $5. Anything special about this?
Typo: by = buy

Topic.Title: NVDA is unusually strong on a Friday

Message.Msg: The folks who complained about the pricing are mostly non-gamers. NVIDIA targets Shield - at least initially - for the gaming enthusiasts, not the casual consumer. NVIDIA had hinted all along that this device was NOT headed for Walmarts or Costco. Tech journalists aren't the buyers. The addressable market size for gaming enthusiasts is well over 50 million worldwide.

Topic.Title: NVDA is unusually strong on a Friday

Message.Msg: Oh, I wasn't talking about the tech journalists themselves, I was talking about reader comments on various online articles, on sites like Ars Technica for example.
Having a physical controller adds a lot more versatility and gameplay options. Nvidia are angling to promote the idea of enhanced controls for Android games.
It's not just the hardware. Cross-platform, open-system is the major selling point.

Topic.Title: NVDA is unusually strong on a Friday

Message.Msg: Agreed, I'm looking forward to good games more than anything when buying a system. I don't know of any good Android games that I'm interested in. I think the good games will come later once game system devices come out in a decent number and start having android games built around a controller. Most don't see android as a possible game system because touch screens and remote controls can only do so much and that's what the experience has been so far. Also, I don't think a lot of gamers know of the quality of the equipment in the system at the moment. If they knew more about it they probably wouldn't scoff at it quite so much. Still $350, even for a quality handheld is really pushing it to far for most gamers. And if you don't have a system that it can connect to, its going to look like its $200 too much.

Topic.Title: NVDA is unusually strong on a Friday

Message.Msg: Doing some math just for fun, assume a 25% market penetration, and NVDA earns a customary 50% of retail, or $175 in rev for each device. That's a 2 billion dollar business (just enthusiasts).

Message.Title: peddie numbers
Message.Msg: John Perdue numbers are out and looksblike Nvidia did surprisingly well.....3.6% increase in ypu shipments last quarter. 7% increase in notebooks. Check out his site for more info or Google it. Higgins

Topic.Title: NVDA is unusually strong on a Friday

Message.Msg: Just a minor note: JH did say on one of the occasions (CES, I believe) that the initial GM for Shield will be around 40%. This number could be in part dictated by economy of scale.

Message.Title: NVIDIA Shield: revolutionizing gaming
Message.Msg: Below is the abstract of an article written by noted tech analyst & consultant Rob Enderle. ""NVIDIA Shield: Revolutionizing Gaming. How this little system could blend reality and virtual reality. #shield I don’t think we really grasp what NVIDA is trying to do with Shield their Android based hand held gaming system. It blends elements of console systems with hand held systems to create what could be a very different multi-screen experience and it destroys the current model of subsidized game systems to provide one that could be far more lucrative to game developers (less expensive games=more games purchased). In the end this may be successful as the best Drone controller ever created and it is so popular I’ve been recently told that retailers have moved up taking preorders to today. (Yes, I also commented on the pre-order moving up in a prior post) suliaDOTcom/channel/all-tech-science/f/79aea1e4-6938-48df-adb0-a85f542a66f3/?source=twitter The full article offers greater insights - well worth your time to read it. techzone360DOTcom/topics/techzone/articles/2013/05/15/338256-nvidia-shield-revolutionizing-gaming.htm

Message.Title: Only 1 out of 10 Galaxy 4S is powered by Samsung's own Exynos 5 octa
Message.Msg: It is easy to understand WHY. Recent teardown analysis by iSuppli disclosed that: Exynos 5 Octa cost ca. $28 (plus LTE) whereas Snapdragon S600 costs $20. Additionally, the Octa has overheating issues, its max clock speed in phones is limited to 1.6GHz, significantly lower than the originally claimed 2.3GHz. Source of the 1:10 processor ratio information: androidauthorityDOTcom/galaxy-s4-exynos-5-octa-chip-211762/ PS: Lets hope that Sammy will eventually come back to NVIDIA as a customer.

Topic.Title: Only 1 out of 10 Galaxy 4S is powered by Samsung's own Exynos 5 octa

Message.Msg: They never claimed that clock speed or anything over 2 GHz. That 2.3 GHz figure is what is claimed for the S800. 1.6 GHz Octa still outperforms 1.9 GHz S600 and the fact that they actually got a 1.6 GHz 28nm quad-A15 into a phone, and it benches like it can use all 4 cores in Geekbench, is a minor miracle and should give you hope for Tegra 4 phones. Samsung's 28nm is brand new and just started ramping which is the reason for the shortage. When Intel's LTE chip XMM7160 is available in volume they will drop the S600 all together and use the Octa everywhere once they have their 28nm process fully ramped. No chance of Nvidia being used, sorry. browserDOTprimatelabsDOTcom/geekbench2/compare/1904492/1950328

Topic.Title: Only 1 out of 10 Galaxy 4S is powered by Samsung's own Exynos 5 octa

Message.Msg: Ibexx, do you think at the point Tegra starts pulling away from the pack that Samsung and Apple will be forced to use Tegra for high-end performance? When it comes to advanced gaming performance and other desirable features that Stark would offer, along with competitive pricing, it would be hard for them to resist especially with the ongoing bad-blood between them, and with the development costs sky rocketing for every iteration. I know both have more than enough money, but time, and not having the needed/desired performance features that Tegra would offer, along with the possibility of others having better performance would weigh in very heavily?.
Typo: SHIED = Shield
